bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, December 18, 1900

div1.p: Reed reports that sixteen Cuban physicians have visited to confirm the experimental yellow fever cases. He responds to Washington social news.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, December 18, 1900
div1.opener:
a kiss &
a Merry X
mas for
Doogy-
Columbia Barracks,
Quemados, Cuba,
December 18, 1900
My precious wifie:
div1.p:
I got two long
and very sweet letters from
my darling Miss Invalid, yes-
terday, and read them as I
rode out to the experimental
station, and how I laughed over
them! Not exactly over the
one of the twelvth of Decr, for that
letter was a sort of dole-
ful contribution to epistolary
composition, but over the
second one, of the 13th, which
was written after my pre-
cious Miss Gouty had read
of our success with “los
mosquitos” and which was
a very, very sweet letter
indeed- If my sweet wifie
and my precious daughter are
proud of me, then I don't
care much for what the
rest of the world thinks.
You would have been de-
lighted, indeed, had you been
here, this afternoon, when
we had sixteen of Havana's
chief physicians out to
see and examine our yel-
low fever cases- It was
to me extremely interesting
to see how cautious they
were, at first, for some
of them came, evidently
already much prejudiced;
but as the examination
went on, they were com-
pelled to admit and did
after awhile admit that
the cases were none other
than genuine yellow fever.
Just one out of the sixteen
thought that perhaps our
mildest case was doubtful,
but the other fifteen acknowl-
edged that the four cases were
cases of yellow fever- Our
last case, which was taken
sick Decr 15th, was just en-
tering his fourth day, and
was so plain that it could
not be disputed- It was
indeed a great victory for
us- As they left the ward
& indeed while there, you
never heard such talking
nor saw such gesticulating
in your life! La lingua es-
pañola had free rent for
once! Our last case is
quite sick, but I think that
he will pull through alright-
Now to change the subject-
say, sweetheart, aren't you
and precious joy putting on
a good deal of style going
to so many teas? Well,
well, well; don't you think
that you should save a few
ftill I get back? Do you
dare tell your Mr Mantee
that he never has time to
go to afternoon teas! You
just wait until I am
S. G, & you will see about
that! So you have a new
dress and bonnet? Well, I
know that you look just too
pretty for anything! I'd give
a dollar to see my joys
all dressed up and ready
for an afternoon tea! What
absurdity, lovie, dear, about
Miss M.'s parlor! Everybody
knows that you are boarding
and nobody would pay the
slightest attention to the
room or furniture. Call
on Mrs. General Merritt- If
you see the General, give
him my love- So you really
saw Willie Sinclair? Where
was “Daisy”? She must have
been there! Without Daisy
no military “Tea” would be
complete. I am so glad
that you went to all of them
and had a good time- Goodness
gracious! no; the S. G. has
not mentioned even any mili-
tary garrison! Jerusalem!
You didn't really believe that
I was in earnest? What
an idea! I had, yesterday,
a cable from the Surgeon Gen-
eral to this effect: “I con-
gratulate you”. This was
in answer to mine of the day
before telling him of our suc-
cess- Of course, I expect a
letter from him within a
few days, but it won't
make me one hundredth as
happy as my darling wifie's
wherein she said that she
was “proud” of me! It was
like a darling sensible
woman to say that I must
not hurry back now on
your account, but that when
I did come, “we would have
a good time”! Indeed, we
will! I don't have to “get
fat & strong”, for I am already
as stout as a lager-beer
drinker and with the appetite
of a “digger” Indian! Now that
the mental strain of the past few
weeks is over, I feel splen-
didly and “sleep like a top”!
I am now taking it very
slowly and enjoying every
day- The recovery of my
purposely-made-sick pa-
tients has naturally made me feel
happy and more thankful
than I can express- But
it is bed-time, and I must say
good-night and the sweetest
dreams to my darling girls!
wednesday morning -- 19th -- I declare,
my sweet children, that your
old Mr. Teesigon came very
near oversleeping himself!
wouldn't that have been
too distressing, since this
letter would then have been
delayed till Saturday! Just
to think that Christmas is
almost here! How the time fairly
flies! December will be gone
before we know it- Precious
Farmer lady please see that
our dear little daughter gets on
the right train in going to Anap-
olis & tell her to be very careful
at Overton on her return. Papa
hopes that her visit will be
a delightful one- From the bot-
tom of his heart, Papa wishes
her dear mother & her darling
self a happy Merry, Merry Christ-
mas and a happy, happy New Year.
Boo! Boo! you precious joys!
kisses & love & love & kisses for my
sweet, sweetest girls!
